#first i would like to check the columns that this file have and check which column i want to keep
US_immigration= pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/gunviolence/MPI-Data-Hub_USImmigFlow_since1820_2018.csv')


# Drop rows with any empty cells
US_immigration=US_immigration.dropna(axis=0, how='any', thresh=None, subset=None, inplace=False)
#Checking columns and rows number
print ('This  dataset has {0} years of data and {1} features'.format(US_immigration.shape[0],US_immigration.shape[1]))

#the immigrants numbers is seprated by commas , I want to remove that to access it as numerical number
US_immigration['Number of Legal Permanent Residents'] = US_immigration['Number of Legal Permanent Residents'].str.replace(',', '')

US_immigration['immigrants'] = pd.to_numeric(US_immigration['Number of Legal Permanent Residents'])
US_immigration.head()
#Checking this
source.eb0016c8:
US_immigration.plot(x='Year', y='immigrants' , figsize=(12,7), color=["blue"])
plt.legend(prop={"size":16})
plt.xlabel('Year', fontsize=14)
plt.ylabel('Count of Immigrants', fontsize=14)
plt.title("Number of Legal Permanent Residents",fontsize = 18);

source.79eacb6e:
#separate year from date
gun_violence['Year'] = pd.DatetimeIndex(gun_violence['date']).year

#aggregate data to group by year and sum the number of victums
gun_violence_agg = gun_violence.groupby('Year')['n_killed'].sum().to_frame()

#pick the correct data range
immigViolence = US_immigration[-6:].drop('Number of Legal Permanent Residents', axis=1)

#set year to be index for joining later
immigViolence = immigViolence.set_index('Year')

#join 2 datasets
JoinedSet = gun_violence_agg.join(immigViolence)

#find the correlation between immigration and number of people killed
JoinedSet.corr()
source.0f7afad7:
# Draw a jointplot between Number of Person Killed Vs Injured in all incidences
sns.jointplot("n_killed",
              "immigrants",
              JoinedSet,
              kind='reg',      # kind : { “scatter” | “reg” | “resid” | “kde” | “hex” }, optional
               )

mass_shooting = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/gunviolence/Mass Shooting 2018 - US states.csv')
mass_shooting = mass_shooting.drop('Operations' , axis = 1)
#renaming the # killed and # injured
mass_shooting = mass_shooting.rename(columns = { "# Killed":"killed","# Injured":"injured"})
mass_shooting.head()
source.46219f98:
killed = mass_shooting.groupby('State', as_index=False).agg({'killed':'sum', 'injured':'sum'})
state_to_code = {'District of Columbia' : 'dc','Mississippi': 'MS', 'Oklahoma': 'OK', 'Delaware': 'DE', 'Minnesota': 'MN', 'Illinois': 'IL', 'Arkansas': 'AR', 'New Mexico': 'NM', 'Indiana': 'IN', 'Maryland': 'MD', 'Louisiana': 'LA', 'Idaho': 'ID', 'Wyoming': 'WY', 'Tennessee': 'TN', 'Arizona': 'AZ', 'Iowa': 'IA', 'Michigan': 'MI', 'Kansas': 'KS', 'Utah': 'UT', 'Virginia': 'VA', 'Oregon': 'OR', 'Connecticut': 'CT', 'Montana': 'MT', 'California': 'CA', 'Massachusetts': 'MA', 'West Virginia': 'WV', 'South Carolina': 'SC', 'New Hampshire': 'NH', 'Wisconsin': 'WI', 'Vermont': 'VT', 'Georgia': 'GA', 'North Dakota': 'ND', 'Pennsylvania': 'PA', 'Florida': 'FL', 'Alaska': 'AK', 'Kentucky': 'KY', 'Hawaii': 'HI', 'Nebraska': 'NE', 'Missouri': 'MO', 'Ohio': 'OH', 'Alabama': 'AL', 'Rhode Island': 'RI', 'South Dakota': 'SD', 'Colorado': 'CO', 'New Jersey': 'NJ', 'Washington': 'WA', 'North Carolina': 'NC', 'New York': 'NY', 'Texas': 'TX', 'Nevada': 'NV', 'Maine': 'ME'}
killed['code'] = killed['State'].apply(lambda x : state_to_code[x])
killed.sort_values(by=['killed'], ascending=False) #sorting by the highest number of people killed

source.f1a6354c:
# **1- Is there any correlation between immigration to the U.S and gun violence between the years 2013 - 2018?**

First : look at the immigration dataset and graph it to visually check the immigration trend since 1820
source.9a979a0d:
## **Overview**

# **Introduction**

Gun violence in America is a huge topic of discussion, Gun violence in The United states has the 28th- highest rate of deaths from gun violence in the world: 4.43 deaths per 100,000 people in 2017 — far greater than what is seen in other wealthy countries.
While some state that gun violence in America has decreased over the last 50 years, the number of mass shootings along with the magnitude of each shooting has increased.

# **Inspiration**

Since I have been living in the U.S for the past year. I became aware of the possibility of active shootings in any public place, by taking a look at the gun violence data, it is my hope to better educate ourselves and others about common questions about these horrific incidents. The significance of researching gun violence is that it can help shed some light on our pre-existing domain knowledge of gun violence in America. Apart from that, it can help determine other insightful information such as the highest percentage of gun violence based on location.

In this Kernel I will be exploring four datasets : 1- US Mass shooting (2018-2020) 2- Gun violence (2012 - 2014) 3- Persons granted U.S. legal permanent resident status during a given fiscal year  4- a gun violence dataset from kaggle (2013-2018). 


My previous questions : 

1. How much gun violence is there in the U.S from the overall mortality rate?
1. do gender and age correlate to gun violence? is there any correlation between race, age , gender?
1. which states experience the most gun violence?   over the years, did gun violence went up or down?

Due to the difficulty of locating datasets that included mortality rates and fatality incidents, I thought I can change the question to correlation between immigration and gun violence.


**Instead ,My research questions will focus on the following:**

1. Is there any correlation between immigration to the U.S and gun violence between the years 2013 - 2018?
1. Which states experienced the most mass shootings over the past two years ?
1. who are the suspect demographics of gun violence between 2012-2014? What about race? sex and intent?
source.200aef0a:
# **Conclusion**

We conclude that there is a positive correlation between immigration and number of people killed between(2013 - 2018), in addition, California experienced the most mass shootings between 2018 - 2020, while alarming, I found it very interesting that California and illinois have the highest number of mass shooting incidents even though both has some of the strictest gun laws in the nations. We also found it bizzare that in terms of states. Furthermore,exploring 2012-2014 dataset, it seemed that  higher gun violence demographics (suspects) are aged between 18 and 35, with the most suspects being male. Additionally , Suicide seems to be the top one intent with an average age of 50 years old between (2012 - 2014) with more than 60k incidents.
source.35c1bfc9: # 2. Which states experienced the most mass shootings over the past two years ?
source.0f57baa2: From this table ,it shows that CA , TX and MO were the top three states having mass shootings since 2018, WA State is the in the middle of this list.
source.1c8da94b: This graph shows that the highest number of gun related incidents demographics are white citizens followed by black citizents,this doesnt necessarily mean homocide as the data have both homocide and suicide gun violence.
source.f2fb9478:
From this table , there seem to be a positive correlation between the number of people killed and the number of immigration between 2013 - 2018.
I believe I could have tackled this better , It should be compared to the number of incidents rather than the number of people being killed and then check the correlation again.
source.7650d218: This  graph represents the immigration trend since 1825 , between the years of (1925 - 1945 ) we can see a sharp decrease in immigration granted , and that can be explained by the great depression after world war 1 an the start of world war 2. Additionally , we can see a sharp increase in the 1990s and that can be explained by the "Immigration act of 1990" signed into law by Geroge.H.W Bush in which It provided family-based immigration visa, created five distinct employment based visas, categorized by occupation, and a diversity visa program that created a lottery to admit immigrants from "low admittance" countries or countries where their citizenry was underrepresented in the U.S.
source.9073544e:
# Future Work

In the future, we can separate the analysis of gun violence incidents by race to also include intent to give us more of an idea about the intent distribution in addition to the race. We can also include data about the population percentages of each race to have an idea about the rate of incidents per capita of a certain race.
We can also dive deeper into the immigration data to see if we can extract gun crime committed by immigrants and compare that to the rate committed by citizens, to try and formulate an estimated rate of danger from immigrants and maybe even come up with prediction models that can predict the potential increase (or decrease, which is quite likely) of gun crime related to accepting new immigrants in a certain state.
source.7cbf24f1:
# **Data Profile**

The Datasets I will be working with today are the following:

1. gun-violence-data_01-2013_03-2018.csv - The CSV file contains data for all recorded gun violence incidents in the US between January 2013 and March 2018, this dataset is avaliable kaggle, and was originally downloaded from gunviolencearchive.org.
1. MPI-Data-Hub_USImmigFlow_since1820_2018.csv - the original source for the data was from Migration Policy Institute tabulations of U.S. Department of Homeland Security, Office of Immigration Statistics, Yearbook of Immigration Statistics (various years)
Link :https://www.migrationpolicy.org/programs/data-hub/charts/Annual-Number-of-US-Legal-Permanent-Residents
1. Mass Shooting 2018 - US states.csv - This CSV file was obtained from gunviolencearchive.org , this data include mass shootings that happened in 43 states over the last two years, the definition of mass shooting in this data seems to be if number of killed and injured is above four.Gun Violence Archive (GVA) is a not for profit corporation formed in 2013 to provide free online public access to accurate information about gun-related violence in the United States. 
Link : https://www.gunviolencearchive.
1. full_data.csv - This data was obtained from data.world , the dataset is by Alex Zelenak in which it contains the gun violence incidens between 2012 -2014, the dataset doesnt include the number of people killed , however it includes the intent of killing.
Link:https://data.world/azel/gun-deaths-in-america




**Prior Work**
some prior work includes a report done by the U.S department of Justice that describes homicide trends and patterns in the united states from 1998 through 2008. This links directly to my research as it provides trends based on sex, race age and type of homicides. A link to this report:

http://michellawyers.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Enos-Ex-B.pdf (Links to an external site.)


Another piece of research looks into immigration and gun violence which use regression models to check if immigration and race connected to it affect homicide rates. It would be beneficial to build on the understanding of their hypothesis testing  and their statistical method to tackle it.

Schnapp, P. (2015). Identifying the Effect of Immigration on Homicide Rates in U.S. Cities: An Instrumental Variables Approach. Homicide Studies, 19(2), 103–122. https://doi.org/10.1177/1088767914528907 (Links to an external site.)

Regarding terms, I will be focusing on incident date, race, age, (perhaps the number of casualties) and location and the overall gun incidents from a set of fatal incidents.
